text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to state that any goods to Northern Ireland from third countries (such as China or the US) must meet all EU product safety standards. The candidate answer addresses this under section 5, stating: \"If they are not clearly confined to NI use/consumption (or the trader isn’t authorised / can’t satisfy conditions), they will face red-lane style requirements and potentially EU duty depending on the at-risk rules.\" Furthermore, it explicitly states regarding China: \"Third-country imports (e.g., China \u2192 NI) are not automatically privileged; absent strong NI-only assurances, they face stricter handling.\" Since NI remains subject to EU law for goods entering the EU market (which is the default assumption for third-country imports unless proven otherwise via the Green Lane), this aligns with the requirement that such goods must meet EU standards or face the Red Lane/full requirements, which encompasses product safety standards.", "criterion_id": "e4a1ae1b-a58e-4d31-bec4-4cf261c4a1c4"}
